etymologies: late 19th century; earliest use found in John Stainer (1840–1901), musicologist and composer. From French sextolet from classical Latin sextus sixth + French -olet (in triolet)

definitions: A group of six notes of equal length, to be played in the time of a smaller number of notes of the same kind, typically four, and usually designated by a figure 6.

notes.text: A sextolet can consist either of two triplets divided equally into six notes, or of two triplets, accented on the first and fourth notes; the latter is now the more common form.
